Modification of Moment-Based Tail Index Estimator: Sums versus Maxima

Natalia Markovich and Marijus Vaiƒçiulis
Abstract

In this paper, we continue the investigation of the SRCEN estimator of the extreme value index Œ≥ùõæ\gamma (or the tail index Œ±=1/Œ≥ùõº1ùõæ\alpha=1/\gamma) proposed in MCE for Œ≥>1/2ùõæ12\gamma>1/2. We propose a new estimator based on the local maximum. This, in fact, is a modification of the SRCEN estimator to the case Œ≥>0ùõæ0\gamma>0. We establish the consistency and asymptotic normality of the newly proposed estimator for i.i.d. data. Additionally, a short discussion on the comparison of the estimators is included.

Keywords:
asymptotic normality, extreme value index, mean squared error, tail index

Typically, the estimators, whose constructions are based on the grouping of the observations into the blocks, are well suited for recursive on-line calculations. The discussion on on-line estimation of the parameter Œ≥>0ùõæ0\gamma>0 can be found in Section 1.2.3 of Mark .

There are situations when data can be divided naturally into blocks but only the largest observations within blocks (the block-maxima) are available. Several such examples are mentioned in Qi , see also Cede , where battle deaths in major power wars between 1495 and 1975 were analyzed. Then the estimator Œ≥^N(2)‚Äã(m)superscriptsubscript^ùõæùëÅ2ùëö\hat{\gamma}_{N}^{(2)}(m) can be applied while the estimators Œ≥^Nsubscript^ùõæùëÅ\hat{\gamma}_{N} and Œ≥^N(1)‚Äã(m)superscriptsubscript^ùõæùëÅ1ùëö\hat{\gamma}_{N}^{(1)}(m) are not applicable.

We will formulate our assumptions in terms of a so-called quantile function VùëâV of the d.f. FùêπF, which is defined as the left continuous generalized inverse:

The domain of attraction condition (1) can be stated in the following way in terms of VùëâV: regarding the d.f. FùêπF, (1) holds if and only if for all x>0ùë•0x>0,

First our result states that Œ≥^N(2)‚Äã(m)superscriptsubscript^ùõæùëÅ2ùëö\hat{\gamma}_{N}^{(2)}(m) is a weakly consistent estimator for Œ≥>0ùõæ0\gamma>0. Theorem 1.1

it holds

where ‚ÜíPsuperscript‚ÜíP{\buildrel\rm P\over{\to}} denotes convergence in probability.

for some Œ¥>0ùõø0\delta>0. Then for the sequence m=m‚Äã(N)ùëöùëöùëÅm=m(N) satisfying (5) it holds

Œ≥^N(2)‚Äã(m)‚ÜíPŒ≥.superscript‚ÜíPsuperscriptsubscript^ùõæùëÅ2ùëöùõæ\hat{\gamma}_{N}^{(2)}(m)\ {\buildrel\rm P\over{\to}}\ \gamma. (8)

As usual, in order to get asymptotic normality for estimators the so-called second-order regular variation condition in some form is assumed. We recall that the function VùëâV is said to satisfy the second-order condition if for some measurable function A‚Äã(t)ùê¥ùë°A(t) with the constant sign near infinity, which is not identically zero, and A‚Äã(t)‚Üí0‚Üíùê¥ùë°0A(t)\to 0 as t‚Üí‚àû‚Üíùë°t\to\infty,

limt‚Üí‚àûV‚Äã(t‚Äãx)V‚Äã(t)‚àíxŒ≥A‚Äã(t)=xŒ≥‚ÄãxœÅ‚àí1œÅsubscript‚Üíùë°ùëâùë°ùë•ùëâùë°superscriptùë•ùõæùê¥ùë°superscriptùë•ùõæsuperscriptùë•ùúå1ùúå\lim_{t\to\infty}\frac{\frac{V(tx)}{V(t)}-x^{\gamma}}{A(t)}=x^{\gamma}\frac{x^{\rho}-1}{\rho} (9)

holds for all x>0ùë•0x>0 with œÅ<0ùúå0\rho<0, which is a second order parameter. The function A‚Äã(t)ùê¥ùë°A(t) measures the rate of convergence of V‚Äã(t‚Äãx)/V‚Äã(t)ùëâùë°ùë•ùëâùë°V(tx)/V(t) towards xŒ≥superscriptùë•ùõæx^{\gamma} in (4), and |A‚Äã(t)|‚ààR‚ÄãVœÅùê¥ùë°ùëÖsubscriptùëâùúå|A(t)|\in RV_{\rho}, see Geluk .

In this paper, we assume a second order condition stronger than (9). Namely, we assume that we are in Hall‚Äôs class of models (see Hall1 ), where

V‚Äã(t)=C‚ÄãtŒ≥‚Äã(1+œÅ‚àí1‚ÄãA‚Äã(t)‚Äã(1+o‚Äã(1))),t‚Üí‚àûformulae-sequenceùëâùë°ùê∂superscriptùë°ùõæ1superscriptùúå1ùê¥ùë°1ùëú1‚Üíùë°V(t)=Ct^{\gamma}\left(1+\rho^{-1}A(t)\left(1+o(1)\right)\right),\quad t\to\infty (10)

with A‚Äã(t)=Œ≥‚ÄãŒ≤‚ÄãtœÅùê¥ùë°ùõæùõΩsuperscriptùë°ùúåA(t)=\gamma\beta t^{\rho}, where C>0ùê∂0C>0, Œ≤‚àà‚Ñù‚àñ{0}ùõΩ‚Ñù0\beta\in\mathbb{R}\setminus\{0\} and œÅ<0ùúå0\rho<0. The relation (10) is equivalent to

(11)

The rest of the paper is organized as follows. In the next section we investigate the asymptotic mean squared error (AMSE) of the introduced estimator, and compare this estimator with several classical estimators, using the same methodology as in Peng . The last section contains the proofs of the results.

2 Comparison

The AMSE of the estimator Œ≥^N(2)‚Äã(m)superscriptsubscript^ùõæùëÅ2ùëö\hat{\gamma}_{N}^{(2)}(m) is given by

(15)

as m‚Üí‚àû‚Üíùëöm\to\infty.

Applying the last asymptotic relation we obtain immediately

|R2,m|={O‚Äã(m‚àí1‚à®œÅ‚à®(1‚àí2‚ÄãŒ≥)‚Äãln‚Å°(m)),‚àí1‚à®œÅ‚â†1‚àí2‚ÄãŒ≥,O‚Äã(m1‚àí2‚ÄãŒ≥‚Äãln2‚Å°(m)),‚àí1‚à®œÅ=1‚àí2‚ÄãŒ≥subscriptùëÖ2ùëöcasesùëÇsuperscriptùëö1ùúå12ùõæùëö1ùúå12ùõæùëÇsuperscriptùëö12ùõæsuperscript2ùëö1ùúå12ùõæ\left|R_{2,m}\right|=\left\{\begin{array}[]{ll}O\left(m^{-1\vee\rho\vee(1-2\gamma)}\ln(m)\right),&\hbox{$-1\vee\rho\not=1-2\gamma$},\\ O\left(m^{1-2\gamma}\ln^{2}(m)\right),&\hbox{$-1\vee\rho=1-2\gamma$}\end{array}\right.

and |R1,m|=o‚Äã(|R2,m|)subscriptùëÖ1ùëöùëúsubscriptùëÖ2ùëö\left|R_{1,m}\right|=o\left(\left|R_{2,m}\right|\right) as m‚Üí‚àû‚Üíùëöm\to\infty.
